ygData.subject: Re: [neat] Re: Bloat
ygData.msgSnippet: ... I think most NEAT implementations perform only one structural mutation at a time. If you did two or more then there s a good chance that one of them would

Derek James wrote:

>On Fri, 04 Jun 2004 00:42:41 +0100, Colin Green <cgreen@...> wrote:
>  
>
>>Consider the problem from the other direction then. If all of of these
>>useless structures aren't participating positively in a search (on the
>>whole) then every single improvement seen in a population must come from
>>immediately beneficial single mutations. 
>>    
>>
>
>Well, that's not entirely accurate.  In any new individual generated
>in NEAT, there could be a very large number of mutations at once. 
>Many of its connection weights may be mutated at once, along with the
>addition (or subtraction) of a fairly large number of topological
>features.
>  
>
I think most NEAT implementations perform only one structural mutation 
at a time. If you did two or more then there's a good chance that one of 
them would be good but would get cancelled out by the deleterious effect 
of the others - I would expect most structural mutations to have such a 
deleterious effect, and only a few to be neutral or beneficial. As for 
weight mutations, these *are* being done in large numbers at a time but 
I was really talking in the context of structural mutations, you don't 
normally get bloat from weight mutations - well you might if the weights 
change in such a way as to make some connections redundant (neutral).

>Thus, ten or twenty mutations at once might produce an increase in
>fitness, which is quite a bit different from benefit arising from a
>single mutation.  (Unless you're considering all of these events as a
>single mutation.)
>  
>
But it is highly unlikely that twenty random mutations will ever result 
in finding a beneficial structure because they are untested and 
therefore they will mostly be deleterious. Performing single 
[structural] mutations and keeping the neutral ones around for the next 
generation is far more likely to find you a good series of mutations.

>  
>
>>I'm reminded of past arguments that creationists have used against
>>evolution,  it goes something like - "I can't see how some biological
>>structures came about because they seem like too much of a jump, there
>>doesn't seem to be any possible gradual evolutionary steps that produced
>>certain structures. therefore they were designed."  
>>    
>>
>
>Hey...you aren't actually comparing me to a creationist, are you?  I
>might take offense at that. ;)
>  
>
:) Just don't get me started on *that* one.

>>I think this is
>>because sometimes jumps are made, so e.g. a piece of  DNA that codes for
>>a single protein might get accidentally copied into part of the genome
>>that describes high-level morphology and instead of describing a protein
>>it now describes, say, a vibration sensitive hair. 
>>    
>>
>
>You're talking about a piece of genetic material that already encodes
>for something adaptive.  Which, again, is quite different from simply
>having a glob of *untested* morphology suddenly hooked up to the stuff
>around it and suddenly increasing the fitness of the organism.
>  
>
As Ken already pointed out, in the gene's new context it may as well be 
a 'glob' of junk. It is a protein sequence that got used in a totally 
different context in which it's old meaning is completely lost. But it 
happened to describe something useful when interpreted as high-level 
morphology because biological systems use very flexible and forgiving 
representation systems. So most of the base pairs would be ignored and 
would still be junk in the new context, and most of what isn't ignored 
would probably describe junk in the phenotype, but that new structure in 
the phenotype included a hair attached to a nerve and could therefore 
detect sound. Natural selection can then remove all of the new junk in 
the phenotype and refine the hair, but a lot of junk would probably 
remain in the DNA.

Now I realise that some may think that I've argued myself into a corner 
here, since this could be interpreted to be the opposite of my above 
argument about multiple mutations being very unlikely to be good. But as 
I say, I think this only works in biology because of the flexible 
representation system(s). Since we have a rigid rep. system (in NEAT) 
it's far more efficient to add structure incrementaly and to allow for 
'jumps' in functionality by allowing neutral structure to accumulate.

>>So anyway, what I was proposing was a method of getting the best of both
>>worlds. If excess structure is important then keep it, but if the search
>>has stagnated for a period of time then I would say that the excess
>>structures have now had plenty of time to prove themselves - and failed.
>>They have crossed the line from being possible useful structures into
>>being useless junk (bloat). 
>>    
>>
>
>It would be interesting to see if this view could be tested
>empirically.  It was my understanding that the philosophy of NEAT was
>essentially gradualist in its approach to adding structure, and that
>was part of the appeal of it to me.  It sounds as if you and Ken are
>both now arguing more for the approach of jumping, via allowing chunks
>of untested morphology to accumulate in the hope that they will
>eventually spontaneously contribute to increased fitness.
>
>  
>
I think Ken and other have covered this, I would just like to copy in a 
paragraph from John though...

>As for the idea of pruning a stagnant species, that's not all that 
>good...when you start going forward again, you would undo your pruning as 
>you look for a way to move forward.  You would need to wait until the 
>stagnant species has broken out of that stagnation, and THEN prune.  But I 
>think your best bet is to wait until you have found an acceptable solution, 
>and then do a phase that supports pruning in order to optimize that 
>solution.
>

Yes that makes more sense :)  So if some of the neutral structure 
becomes positive then you have moved into a new and better position in 
the overall search space, this warrants searching around that space for 
a while, but! you are still likely to have some of the neutral structure 
that didn't become positive. This means you are searching through a 
higher search dimensionality than you really should be - you have found 
a new promising point in the search space so you don't really want that 
speculative neutral structure, not until you start to stagnate again. 
Therefore I think it would be a refinement of the NEAT search process to 
prune neutral structure from the genomes at that point.

Colin
